channel.title: Too Poor to Pay Attention
channel.description:
Being as I am, too poor to pay attention and as broke as a joke, I thought I might speak a few words on our economy. Nothing to do with cash, because everybody in America already knows CREAM (Cash Rules Everything Around Me). And if I were to speak about the exchange of value what value would I be speaking of and of what exchange? There are many ways to filter the infinite knowledge of the universe and repackage it to make it manageable, to pick up a shard of broken glass and make a mirror, but all these are finite and only take us away from the infinity around us. Yet ignorance is not bliss. Love, the only power which I know, the only thing which allows me to [b]begin[/b] to understand anything, is what I would like to speak of. Quite frankly the presidential election in the United States is getting uglier than a bag of smashed assholes. In the words of Ron Paul who was speaking at the time of a different sort of economy;
The president also tells us that Senators McCain and Obama will join him at the White House today in order to figure out how to get the bipartisan bailout passed. The two senators would do their country much more good if they stayed on the campaign trail debating who the bigger celebrity is, or whatever it is that occupies their attention these days.
Indeed realpolitik is a meaningless chuckle in this political vacuum. I fail to find any substantial difference between the candidates or their policies and wonder idly sometimes who is more confused, those voting for McCain out of confusion and fear or those voting for Obama out of hope. I find this situation extremely unrighteous but perhaps my sight is narrowed by trying to look to wide; my opinion of the candidates as clones is not valid and I would like to know if anybody can wax sophomoric on the tangible differences between the two.* I believe they are the same because the power of love is dead within them, they are actors on a very dark stage in a theater which is burning down and nobody seems to care. There is the technology now and has been for a long time to produce energy enough for a sustainable number of human beings on this planet as well as food and sustenance for this finite number, yet one thing technology cannot produce is peace and happiness of the soul, and so CREAM onward, for there are already too many of us on this blue green marble and not one of us knows just what we are doing here. [size=1pt] *[no I don't support Ron Paul for president][/size]

item.title: Too Poor to Pay Attention
item.dc:creator: @sanga282 sanga282
item.description:
@sanga282 wrote:

Speljohan:

Glad someone else shares my point of view. America has been shit since the early 1900’s. It all started with incompetent greedy fools like J.D. Rockafeller.

they all use to be cool brits then they fuckin went on the yankwank

Read full topic

item.title: Too Poor to Pay Attention
item.dc:creator: @PaulT PaulT
item.description:
@PaulT wrote:

The people doesn't run america, the government doesn't, the president doesn't. The oil companies do.

The people are America just as the people of any country are that country and though the government can control the thoughts of a people, to a point it, can never ensnare their spirit. Corporations “Run” our country but it is still individuals, the cogs within the machine, which do the doing. It is too easy to laugh in the face of a great evil industrial machine when we could instead take personal, if shared, responsibility. Kurt Vonnegut said something like 'We are all hopeless fossil fuel addicts and are leaders are committing violent crimes to get us more."

Read full topic

item.title: Too Poor to Pay Attention
item.dc:creator: @Speljohan Speljohan
item.description:
@Speljohan wrote:

PaulT:

[quote]The person with most money wins the election. I’m surprised you haven’t seen this before. The american election has always been a question about power. It’s all rigged because a person can’t win unless the oil companies decide he should.

There are a great many books out now on how possible it is for elections to be thrown because of the new electronic voting machines with no paper record (instituted ene mass after the ‘Constitutional Crises’ in Florida eight years ago) and there is much evidence to suggest that this has been going on (Investigative Journalist Greg Palast) I agree with you, the candidates are all vetted by corporate interest and live by CREAM. I ask then what does it matter if our election is rigged?

I watched the debate last night and I found my point of view vindicated in regards to the clonelyness of the candidates. The most anti-war thing Obama could think of was sending more troops to Afghanistan and maybe possibly reducing troops in Iraq a little bit over a long period of time. One of the worst moments in the whole debate came when the moderator started a question by stating that the next president would “Rule” the nation. What? The president doesn’t rule our country, or at least, he’s not supposed to. It rankled particularly much because he went on to compare America as a “Democracy” to Russia and China which were “Not Democracies”.

John McCain did a fair impression of Satan, saying that he would quite possibly cut all federal spending except defense and veterans affairs, chuckling maniacally about nothing, saying he would cut ‘Corruption’ out of government (by centralizing government more and giving less to states and also “Scrubbing” the government clean, whatever that means) and generally just scaring the shit out of anyone with two brain cells to rub together and make a spark of thought.[/quote]The people doesn’t run america, the government doesn’t, the president doesn’t. The oil companies do.

Read full topic

item.title: Too Poor to Pay Attention
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

What the US needs is a complete reorganisation. They should look at the political systems in Europe.

In my eyes the US is a great country, I’d love going there and even living there. But it’s political system sucks. I myself am a liberal, right wing person. I support a light version of a free market. The government should make rules, guidelines, minimum/maximum prices, etc. The rest is for the market. In the Netherlands we have rules about mortgages. If someone can’t afford it, he can’t get it. There is support for those without a job (altough I’d rather see this change a bit). I could go on and on about how a country should look like in my eyes. America just went too far, it’s market system is great on the short run (short run can even mean 100 years) but on the long run it sucks.

Read full topic

@PaulT wrote:

The person with most money wins the election. I'm surprised you haven't seen this before. The american election has always been a question about power. It's all rigged because a person can't win unless the oil companies decide he should.

There are a great many books out now on how possible it is for elections to be thrown because of the new electronic voting machines with no paper record (instituted ene mass after the ‘Constitutional Crises’ in Florida eight years ago) and there is much evidence to suggest that this has been going on (Investigative Journalist Greg Palast) I agree with you, the candidates are all vetted by corporate interest and live by CREAM. I ask then what does it matter if our election is rigged?

I watched the debate last night and I found my point of view vindicated in regards to the clonelyness of the candidates. The most anti-war thing Obama could think of was sending more troops to Afghanistan and maybe possibly reducing troops in Iraq a little bit over a long period of time. One of the worst moments in the whole debate came when the moderator started a question by stating that the next president would “Rule” the nation. What? The president doesn’t rule our country, or at least, he’s not supposed to. It rankled particularly much because he went on to compare America as a “Democracy” to Russia and China which were “Not Democracies”.

John McCain did a fair impression of Satan, saying that he would quite possibly cut all federal spending except defense and veterans affairs, chuckling maniacally about nothing, saying he would cut ‘Corruption’ out of government (by centralizing government more and giving less to states and also “Scrubbing” the government clean, whatever that means) and generally just scaring the shit out of anyone with two brain cells to rub together and make a spark of thought.

item.description:
@Speljohan wrote:

[quote=“R.I.P RSC, post:18, topic:233303”]PaulT!!!

But anyways, I agree. The elections aren’t about politics anymore. It’s all about the image of the candidates. The American politic system is flawed, the president’s are just spokespersons for the people with knowledge. I failed to see this before, and it sounds like conspiracy shit (which I don’t like). The goal of the party’s is to get the plebs behind them by using sympathic people.[/quote]The person with most money wins the election. I’m surprised you haven’t seen this before. The american election has always been a question about power. It’s all rigged because a person can’t win unless the oil companies decide he should.
